module.p: dhe of is the (leniting) partitive preposition.

section.p:
The default form of the partitive preposition is simply dhe –
dhe thaigh of a house
dhe dh’aislingean of dreams
dhe Nirribhidh of Norway
dhe thrì làithean of three days

Before a word beginning with a vowel or fh-, dhe is reduplicated to dhe dh’ –
dhe dh’aislingean of dreams
dhe dh’Èirinn of Ireland
dhe dh’ochd rionnagan of eight stars
Note that dhe is often spelled (and even pronounced) as de. Also, dhe is often reduced to just a, even in writing.

When the immediately following word is a singular form of the definite article, the linking form dhen is used –
dhen an taigh of the house
dhen a’ bhaile of the town But –
dhe na h-aislingean of the dreams, rather than dhen na h-aislingean
Note that dhen an and dhen a’ often reduce to just dhen – dhen taigh, dhen bhaile. Note also that the non-lenited form den is often found instead.

Fused forms are sometimes found when the immediately following word is a possessive determiner –
dhe mo thaigh of my house ≈ d[h]em thaigh
dhe do bhaile of your town ≈ d[h]ed bhaile
dhe a h-òran of her song ≈ d[h]e h-òran
dhe a chraoibh of his tree ≈ d[h]e chraoibh
dhe ar n-achadh of our field ≈ d[h]er n-achadh
dhe ur leapannan of your beds ≈ d[h]ur leapannan
dhe an taighean of their houses ≈ d[h]en taighean
dhe am baile of their town ≈ d[h]em baile
Note that these fused forms are rather awkward and sometimes ambiguous and hence are best avoided in writing nowadays.

Conjugated prepositions are used in place of dhe mi, dhe thu, ... , dhe iad –
dhiom of me
dhiot of you
dhith of her/it
dheth of him/it
dhinn of us
dhibh of you
dhiubh of them

There are also emphatic forms (cf. dhe mise, dhe thusa, ... , dhe iadsan) –
dhiomsa of me
dhiotsa of you
dhithse of her/it
dhethsan of him/it
dhinne of us
dhibhse of you
dhiubhsan of them
Note that the form dhethsan breaks the ‘slender-to-slender, broad-to-broad’ spelling rule, and hence is sometimes found written with a hyphen – dheth-san.

Finally, there are also reflexive forms (cf. dhe mi fhìn, dhe thu fhèin, ... , dhe iad fhèin) –
dhiom fhìn of myself
dhiot fhèin of yourself
dhith fhèin of herself/itself
dheth fhèin of himself/itself
dhinn fhìn of ourselves
dhibh fhèin of yourselves
dhiubh fhèin of themselves

Some examples –
older pedagogical examples –
Bha an latha brèagha blàth is thug an athair leis Iain agus Anna anns a’ chàr. Chaidh iad sìos taobh an locha is stad iad aig àite bòidheach gorm. Chuir iad an càr a stigh gu taobh an rathaid is thug iad brat a mach as a’ chàr air son suidhe air. Tha bascaid làn de bhiadh aca is tha iad a’ dol a ghabhail an tea air a’ chnocan ghorm. [...]
The day was lovely and warm and their father took John and Ann in the car. They went down the side of the lake and they stopped at a beautiful green place. They put the car into the side of the road and they took a blanket out of the car for sitting on. They have a basket full of food and they are going to have their tea on the little green hill. [...] td. 6–7 biadh
food

Some examples –
older pedagogical examples –
Bha an latha brèagha blàth is thug an athair leis Iain agus Anna anns a’ chàr. Chaidh iad sìos taobh an locha is stad iad aig àite bòidheach gorm. Chuir iad an càr a stigh gu taobh an rathaid is thug iad brat a mach as a’ chàr air son suidhe air. Tha bascaid làn de bhiadh aca is tha iad a’ dol a ghabhail an tea air a’ chnocan ghorm. [...]
The day was lovely and warm and their father took John and Ann in the car. They went down the side of the lake and they stopped at a beautiful green place. They put the car into the side of the road and they took a blanket out of the car for sitting on. They have a basket full of food and they are going to have their tea on the little green hill. [...] td. 6–7 làn
full
sguir dhe ..., stad dhe ... stop something
